target_text: "OK, great. Software quality is the end result. It has a structural perspective which is the code and the design. It has also an external component which is free of defects and meets the end user requirements."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

Codebook.role: Reflective Qualitative Software Engineering Researcher (PhD Candidate; Discipline: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF Interests: Human-Centered Computing, Software & Hardware Foundations; Bias: interpretivist, socio-technical emphasis)

codebook.justification: [Software quality is the end result.] Teleologically frames quality, privileging outcomes over process and inviting interpretive cutoff points. My CSIS/HCC lens treats 'quality' as negotiated, not fixed.

[a structural perspective] highlights internal attributes; code/design heuristics require expert judgment. My SE stance reads structure via socio-technical maintainability and architectural coherence.
[meets the end user requirements] encodes subjective fit; requirements elicitation and validation are interpretive. HCC bias centers stakeholder sensemaking and situated acceptability.
[free of defects] posits an ideal; defect taxonomies, severity triage, and thresholds are value-laden. My reflexive stance problematizes 'defect' as context-contingent.
